title: Highlights: The first Democratic debate
text:
Highlights: The first Democratic debate 
Updated: Tue, Oct 13 2015, 11:46 PM 
By: CBS 21 Web Staff 
LAS VEGAS -- Front runner Hillary Clinton couldn’t escape the email scandal dogging her campaign. She apologized again but then turned to the issues. 
“Tonight I want not to talk about my emails but what the American people want from the next president of the U.S." Clinton said. 
Her closest challenger, Senator Bernie Sanders, agreed. 
“Enough of the emails, let's talk about the real issues facing America," he said 
Clinton separated herself from Sanders, first on his self-labeled “Democratic Socialism.” 
"We would be making a grave mistake to turn our backs on what built the greatest middle class in the history of the world," Clinton said. 
You can have all the growth you want and it doesn't mean anything if all of the new income and wealth is going to the top 1 percent," Sanders said. 
Clinton and former Maryland Governor Martin O’Malley both challenged Sanders on gun safety legislation. 
“It's time to stand up to pass gun safety legislation,” O’Malley debated. 
Sanders said, “I come from a rural state and the views on gun control in rural states is different than in urban states whether we like it or not.” 
The first debate was a chance for all five Democratic presidential candidates to introduced themselves to voters. 
"I am very clear about my principles," O'Malley said. 
"I have no scandals," Chafee said in his introduction. 
Webb said, "I've also spent half my professional life away from politics." 
Four of the five candidates, all but Jim Webb, specifically mentioned climate change in their opening remarks. Related Stories
